title: AST SpaceMobile delays commercial satellite debut by six months
summary: Supply chain issues have pushed out the launch of AST SpaceMobile’s first operational satellite about six months to late 2023, the cellphone-compatible broadband constellation startup said Aug. 15.

title: Blue Origin scraps original recovery ship for New Glenn boosters
summary: A large ship that Blue Origin planned to convert into a landing platform for New Glenn boosters is instead being sent to the scrapyard as the company changes its recovery plans.

title: Orion Space wins U.S. Space Force contract for on-orbit services experiment
summary: Orion Space Solutions announced Aug. 16 it was selected by the U.S. Space Force to develop three small satellites for a demonstration of on-orbit services in geostationary Earth orbit.

title: SLS rolling to LC-39B for launch, teams prepare for multiple launch trajectories
summary: NASA’s Space Launch System (SLS) rocket completed all pre-launch preparations inside the Vehicle Assembly Building at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida and is conducting its 4.2-mile (6.7-km) journey to Launch Complex 39B.

title: After ICBM test, US stresses it was “not the result of current world events”
summary: Test comes after delays due to Russia, China tensions.

title: Astrobotic bids for Masten Space Systems assets
summary: Astrobotic Technology, a lunar lander developer, has made a formal bid for “substantially all” of the assets of Masten Space Systems, another lander company that filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy last month.

title: China’s spaceplane remains in orbit but clues emerge from recovered launch debris
summary: A Chinese reusable experimental spacecraft remains in orbit nearly two weeks after launch, despite passing directly over its expected landing site early Monday.

title: Ball and Seagate test data storage devices for satellites
summary: Ball Aerospace and Seagate Technology Holdings are working together to develop and test high-capacity commercial data processing and storage devices for spaceflight applications.

title: NASA Awards Next-Generation Spaceflight Computing Processor Contract
summary: NASA’s Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Southern California has selected Microchip Technology Inc. of Chandler, Arizona, to develop a High-Performance Spaceflight Computing (HPSC) processor that will provide at least 100 times the computational capacity of current spaceflight computers.

title: NASA Science Leadership to Hold Town Hall Meeting
summary: NASA will hold a community town hall meeting with Associate Administrator for Science Thomas H. Zurbuchen and his leadership team at 12:30 p.m. EDT Wednesday, Aug. 17.
